00034 
00074 /* Preprocessor directive that conditionally compiles the code that uses the weakly-linked MessageUI.Framework.
00075  This framework is required if you want to include the ability to share activities with email or sms.  By default
00076  the JRENGAGE_INCLUDE_EMAIL_SMS flag should always be set to "1", which can cause errors with the linker if the
00077  framework isn't included, but I figured most apps would want the email and sms sharing ability.  If you don't want
00078  to add the MessageUI.Framework to one or more of your apps that use the JREngage library, you don't have to change
00079  this value to "0" (which could cause merging issues if I make changes later).
00080 
00081  Instead, if you want to override this setting, you need to add the preprocessor flag "OVERRIDE_INCLUDE_EMAIL_SMS"
00082  to your target's GCC_PREPROCESSOR_DEFINITIONS build setting (also listed as "Preprocessor Macros" under the
00083  "GCC 4.2 - Preprocessing" heading). */
00084 #ifndef OVERRIDE_INCLUDE_EMAIL_SMS
00085 #define JRENGAGE_INCLUDE_EMAIL_SMS 1
00086 #endif
00087

00310 @interface JREngage : NSObject <JRSessionDelegate>

00312     JRUserInterfaceMaestro *_interfaceMaestro; /*< \internal Class that handles customizations to the library's UI */

00314     NSMutableArray         *_delegates;        /*< \internal Array of JREngageDelegate objects */

00440 // * Use this function to begin authentication.  The JREngage library will pop up a modal dialog,
00441 // * configured with the given custom interface, possibly skipping the user landing page,
00442 // * and take the user through the sign-in process.
00443 // *
00444 // * @param customInterfaceOverrides
00445 // *   A dictionary of objects and properties, indexed by the set of
00446 // *   \link customInterface pre-defined custom interface keys\endlink,
00447 // *   to be used by the library to customize the look and feel of the user
00448 // *   interface and/or add a native login experience
00449 // *
00450 // * @param skipReturningUserLandingPage
00451 // *   Prevents the dialog from opening to the returning-user landing page when \c YES.  That is, the
00452 // *   dialog will always open straight to the list of providers.  The dialog falls back to the default
00453 // *   behavior when \c NO
00454 // *
00455 // * @note
00456 // * Any values specified in the \e customInterfaceOverrides dictionary will override the corresponding
00457 // * values specified the dictionary passed into the setCustomInterfaceDefaults:() method.
00458 // *
00459 // * @note
00460 // * If you always want to force the user to re=enter his/her credentials, pass \c true to the method
00461 // * setAlwaysForceReauthentication().
00462 // **/
00463 //- (void)showAuthenticationDialogWithCustomInterfaceOverrides:(NSDictionary*)customInterfaceOverrides
00464 //                            skippingReturningUserLandingPage:(BOOL)skipReturningUserLandingPage;
00465 
00467 // * Use this function to begin authentication.  The JREngage library will pop up a modal dialog and
00468 // * take the user through the sign-in process.
00469 // *
00470 // * @param skipReturningUserLandingPage
00471 // *   Prevents the dialog from opening to the returning-user landing page when \c YES.  That is, the
00472 // *   dialog will always open straight to the list of providers.  The dialog falls back to the default
00473 // *   behavior when \c NO
00474 // *
00475 // * @note
00476 // * If you always want to force the user to re=enter his/her credentials, pass \c true to the method
00477 // * setAlwaysForceReauthentication().
00478 // **/
00479 //- (void)showAuthenticationDialogSkippingReturningUserLandingPage:(BOOL)skipReturningUserLandingPage;
00480 
00482 // *
00483 // **/
00484 //- (void)showAuthenticationDialogWithForcedReauthenticationOnLastUsedProvider;
00485 #endif /* DOXYGEN_SHOULD_SKIP_THIS */
00486
